content: Enrollment number – M/18/166  Commonly used study technique – reading lecture notes about 3 times. Make flow charts.do saq  How would you grade your stress? (Low/ Moderate/ High) -moderate    Commonly used coping strategies – watching movies , listening to music    Self-evaluation   Good points of my studying – make a plan for studying during study leave.     Weaknesses of my studying – do not prepare for exam early. Sleepiness     How should I improve my studying? – prepare for the exam as early as possible .     What type of guidance do I need? – someone who can explain that difficult things to understand

Hello! It's great to have the opportunity to chat with you today. I've taken a look at your self-evaluation data sheet, and I must say, it's a good starting point for us to understand how we can work together to enhance your study habits and manage stress more effectively. Let's start by discussing your study techniques. You mentioned that you commonly read lecture notes about three times and make flow charts. That's a solid strategy as it helps in visualizing the information. How do you find this method in terms of retaining information? Do you feel like it helps you grasp the concepts better?
yes it helps to me for memorising names of the drugs

That's fantastic to hear! Visual aids like flow charts can be incredibly effective for memorizing complex information, such as drug names. Since this method works well for you, we might consider how you can expand on it or integrate other techniques to enhance your understanding further, not just memorization. 

Given your interest in improving your study habits, have you tried incorporating active recall techniques into your study sessions? For example, after reading through your notes and creating your flow charts, you could test yourself on the material without looking at your notes. This could be a powerful addition to your study routine, especially for retaining drug names and understanding their uses or side effects. 

Also, you mentioned a desire to start preparing for exams as early as possible to overcome weaknesses like sleepiness and last-minute studying. Setting up a more structured study schedule might help with this. How do you feel about dedicating specific times each day to different subjects or topics, allowing for more consistent review and less cramming closer to exam time?

in these days i have to go o clinicals and i have to study for that as well. so it is difficult to find a more time to study for this exam. so i have to study in less time and memorizing all the theories that will help to pass the exam. can you suggest a method that i can work for my exam considering my situation

Absolutely, balancing clinical duties with exam preparation can indeed be challenging, but with the right strategies, you can make the most of your limited study time. Given your situation, I'd recommend a few approaches that could help you study more efficiently and effectively.

1. **Spaced Repetition**: This technique involves reviewing the material over increasing intervals of time. It's particularly effective for memorization and long-term retention. You could use this method with flashcards, which are great for memorizing drug names, mechanisms of action, indications, and side effects. There are several apps available that can help automate the spaced repetition process for you.

2. **Active Recall**: This goes hand in hand with spaced repetition but focuses on actively stimulating memory during the learning process. Instead of passively reading your notes or flowcharts, ask yourself questions or use flashcards to test your knowledge. This forces your brain to retrieve the information and has been shown to improve memory and learning significantly.

3. **Prioritize Your Study Topics**: Given the limited time, focus on high-yield topics and areas where you feel less confident. Use your clinical experiences to guide what you study. Often, real-world application can help solidify theoretical knowledge.

4. **Integrate Learning with Clinicals**: Try to apply what you're studying to your clinical rotations. For instance, if you're learning about a particular drug, pay extra attention when you encounter patients taking that medication. This can help reinforce your learning and make your study time more effective.

5. **Short Study Sessions**: Since you're pressed for time, try to utilize short, focused study sessions. Even 30 minutes of concentrated study can be incredibly productive if you're using active recall and spaced repetition. This can be more manageable around your clinical schedule than trying to find larger blocks of time.

6. **Peer Learning**: If possible, form a small study group with peers. Teaching and discussing topics with others can significantly enhance understanding and retention. Even if you're all busy, you could arrange quick review sessions or share flashcards and resources.

Remember, quality often trumps quantity when it comes to studying. By using these methods, you can maximize the effectiveness of your study time, even if it's limited. How do you feel about trying some of these strategies?

You're welcome! I'm glad I could offer some suggestions. Remember, it's all about finding what works best for you and adapting these strategies to fit your schedule and learning style. Don't hesitate to tweak and adjust as you go along. And most importantly, be kind to yourself during this process. It's okay to have moments of frustration or to need a break. Your well-being is just as important as your studies.

If you have any more questions, need further clarification, or just want to talk about how things are going, feel free to reach out. I'm here to support you. Good luck with your clinicals and exam preparation. You've got this!
